definition: official authority used for private interests (idiom); to attain private ends by abusing public position
fake/false/artificial/to borrow/if/suppose
see 假掰[gei1 bai1]
vacation

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
only used in 濟濟|济济[ji3 ji3]
to cross a river/to aid or relieve/to be of help
used in place names associated with the Ji River 濟水|济水[Ji3 Shui3]/surname Ji
personal/private/selfish

sentences.english: He said he would not job his son into the position .
sentences.chinese: 他說，他不會假公濟私爲他兒子安排那個職位。

sentences.english: To overdo anything public may lead to jobbery while appropriate selfishness may promote the growth.
sentences.chinese: “公”字過頭可能假公濟私，私心適度也會促進發展。

sentences.english: He said he wouldn't job his son into the position.
sentences.chinese: 他說，他不會假公濟私爲他兒子安排那個職位。

sentences.english: Their jobs were all exposed by the press.
sentences.chinese: 他們假公濟私的勾當全被報紙揭了出來。

definition: unstable/erratic/changeable/fickle
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
to bear grudges
to be stuck/to feel stuck
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
fight to the death/desperate struggle
complete nonsense (idiom)
variant of 誣衊|诬蔑[wu1 mie4]
lit. to sleep on brushwood and taste gall (like King Gou Jian of Yue 勾踐|勾践[Gou1 Jian4]), in order to recall one's humiliations) (idiom)/fig. to maintain one's resolve for revenge
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
to fish in troubled water (idiom); to take advantage of a crisis for personal gain
to plot and kill sb for his property (idiom); to murder for money
it will cause no end of trouble (idiom)
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
to ask for trouble/to invite difficulties
lit. the salted fish turns over (idiom)/fig. to experience a reversal of fortune
